meanings.definition: To exert force on (someone or something) so as to cause movement towards oneself.
meanings.sent1: She had to pull the heavy door to open it.
meanings.sent2: He always pulls the wagon when we go for a walk.
meanings.sent3: The little girl tried to pull her cat closer for a hug.
meanings.sent4: The magnet seemed to pull the metal objects towards it.
meanings.sent5: The superhero's magnetic powers could pull objects from afar.

meanings.definition: A force drawing something towards oneself.
meanings.sent1: The strong pull of the magnet attracted the metal.
meanings.sent2: He felt a pull on the rope as he tugged it towards him.
meanings.sent3: The pull of the vacuum cleaner made cleaning fun for the toddler.
meanings.sent4: The gravitational pull of the moon affects the tides.
meanings.sent5: The pull of the black hole was so strong, nothing could escape it.

meanings.definition: To extract or remove by force.
meanings.sent1: She had to pull out the splinter from her finger.
meanings.sent2: He tried to pull the nail from the wood with all his strength.
meanings.sent3: The magician tried to pull a rabbit out of his hat but found a carrot instead.
meanings.sent4: The detective managed to pull the truth out of the suspect.
meanings.sent5: The dentist had to pull the tooth to relieve the pain.
